THE MYSTERIES OF THE CASTLE: A DRAMATIC TALE, IN THREE ACTS: AS PERFORMED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL, COVENT-GARDEN. WRITTEN BY MILES PETER ANDREWS, ESQ.
LONDON: PRINTED BY W. WOODFALL. FOR T. N. LONGMAN, PATERNOSTER-ROW. 1795.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: FOR the PROLOGUE, and the SONG in praise of HAWKING, the AUTHOR is indebted to his friend Capt. TOPHAM. And he gladly takes this opportunity of acknowledging his obligation for the liberal attention of the MANAGER, and the spirited exertions of all the PERFORMERS.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: LONG has been serv'd from this our motley Stage,
Repasts for various tastes—from youth to age—
To lively Miss, escap'd from Sshool and toil,
Our sports have oft bestow'd the infant smile,
While the rude boy, from Westminster or Eton,
Who "spies," and "quizzes" one, where'er they meet one.
For them, our brilliant Ballets drawn from Greece,
Restore their Greek—without a rod a piece.
While tricks and tumbling honest John employ,
Who drinks his punch aloft, and screams with joy.
The wife is all for music, shakes and thrilling,
Old maids, from soft humanity, love killing:
Each has his taste: for married life may say,
Not oft' two persons think in the same way.
Our Bard, long known to you, this night makes up,
Of various beverage—a kind of cup;
Of Music, Pantomime, and graver scenes,
Perhaps a dash of terror intervenes;
Should not all these sufficient change supply,
If you condemn—there will be—Tragedy.
But, Britons, while a neighbouring nation's crimes,
Have spread war wide, and made these—"Iron Times."
Greet you, the moral virtues of the STAGE,
Which haply may amend an erring age:
That Arts and Sciences may take their place,
That the domestic ties may have their grace,
The rights of sweet humanity be known,
And freedom fixed by law, reign like your own?

div.p: SCENE—MESSINA AND PARTS ADJACENT, AFTERWARDS ON THE COAST OF CALABRIA.

body.head: The Mysteries of the Castle: A DRAMATIC TALE.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: —A View of the City of MESSINA, the BAY, MOUNT AETNA, &c, &c.
SICILIAN GIRLS coming from the Hills, going to Market with Eggs, Garden Herbs, Fruits, &c. &c.

lg.l: We village maids to market go;
And with jest and jocund lay,
Nor stop to make our purpose known,
Till we've reached the destin'd town.
Then with smiles and court'sy meet,

div.stage: As they go off calls after them.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: —Holloa! Damsels! Stop a little, and I'll ease you of your wares, I'll warrant you. Well, thank Heaven, we're arrived in a chearful country at last. looking about Bless me! What a charming air! And what a charming appetite it gives one! I have scarcely swallowed any thing but dust for these three weeks, but here ends our tedious journey—Yonder is the city of Messina, and hard by resides the man my master is in search of—Why my master has left Savoy, to seek this interview with poor dead Julia's jealous husband, I am yet to learn—Oh! Here he comes.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
—At length, Valoury, the hurry of travelling is over—you now will have time to re
cover your fatigue.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p:
Yes, Signor Carlos, and to lose my appetite I hope; for the one is as irksome a com
panion as the other.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Would my distrestes could be as easily removed as yours—The shade of my departed Julia haunts me at every turn, and her injured memory calls aloud for vengeance.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p:
Ah! Sir, if grief or resentment could restore her to life, I'd starve myself into a passion with pleasure; but as that is impossible, might I advise you, Signor, I should recommend a tem
perate meal or two, before we proceed any fur
ther.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
Temperate! Valoury, can anguish in
supportable be temperate! Listen to the story of my heart—That Julia, the hapless wife of the im
perious Count Montoni, whom thou saw'st interr'd at Palermo—

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p:
And a melancholy sight it was, Sig
nor Carlos—I remember I was just sitting down to an excellent barbacue, smoking hot, when the procession passed the window; but so it is, when
ever a man is upon the point of being happy, some cursed thing or other always interferes to chill his prospects.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
Think, Valoury, of an attachment begun almost in childhood, and improved with growing years; when love's soft wishes were sanc
tioned by reason, and dear expectation nourished by consenting friends.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p:
What then was the cause of your los
ing her?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
Her father's avarice and ambition. This proud, indignant Lord, the Count Montoni, with large possessions, and extended power, was
captivated with my Julia's blooming charms, and, do I live to repeat it, tore her from me in the mo
ment when she was to have been mine for ever.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: But how came the Lady to consent?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
There thou hast touched the cord of anguish in my breast; that drove me from my native home, to seek in solitude a calm, which, alas, Valoury, thy master's heart can never more experience; that brings me back again on the wings of rage, and vengeance, to demand atone
ment for wrongs too great to be endured.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p:
Bless me, Sir! Has any thing hap
pened lately?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Yes; from the amiable Constantia, the only surviving sister of my hapless love, I learn by papers found since her decease, that the most infernal arts were put in practice by the Count and his adherents, to bend the timid fair one to their cruel purpose.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: Mercy on me! My hair stands on end. They hinted too at Palermo, that the Lady's death was sudden and extraordinary.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: By basest forgery she was induced to believe I had already been wedded to another.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: To another indeed! As if Gentlemen of your prudent turn of mind, did not think one wife at a time quite sufficient.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
But the hour of retribution is at hand; meanwhile bear this letter to Constantia—Her father, old Fractioso, is one of the Chief Magi
strates in the city. I would on no account that he should hear of my return; therefore be careful to deliver it into her own hands.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p:
Trust it to me, Signor, and Dad shall know no more of the business, than an Ex-Mini
ster does of the Cabinet, or a fashionable husband of his wife's bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
From her you may learn tidings of my friend, Hilario, whose return from Germany I ex
pect about this time; and I know, notwithstand
ing her father's obstinate prohibition, Constantia is not insensible to his deserts.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: And a charming Gentleman he is; would he were here—his chearfulness would drive away your honour's melancholy—sorrow with him, is like a bad Signet, it squeezes the surface; but leaves no impression.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Hark! Here come the Falconers with their Hawks—we must not be seen, retire—be expeditious, and meet me at the Hotel.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: At the Hotel—ah! Sir, you need not doubt my expedition; for sure no love sick girl in Europe can be more sharp set than is your honor's very hungry, humble servant.

div.stage: Enter MONTAUBAN in a Falconer's dress, with Hawks, &c.
A train of Sportsmen all in shewy apparel, with high plumes of feathers.

lg.l: Heighlo! Heighlo! The morning is up,
We've each of us had a stirrupping cup,
And of game we'll bring home a load—
Uncouple the Spaniels, and let the dogs try,
See the Partridge there on the wing;
Quick, quick! Jolly Falconer, let the hawks fly,
'Tis a pleasure fit for a king.
Then mark the swift Hawk—see him now make his stoop,
Ah! Down goes the game! Call him in then! La leup! La leup!

lg.head: II.
lg.l: Barons of old, and Princes so high,
The health of the field, and the Falconer's cry,
Drown'd even the pipes of their wives:
Our Hawks, they are a Gallantie show,
With rings and feathers so fine;
The Falconer laughs at sports below,
What Sportsmen to joys then inferior wou'd stoop,
When the summit of sporting is Hawking! La leup! La leup!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Montauban, draw near; thy activity and diligence are commendable—are the Hawks strong and eager?

sp.speaker: Montauban.
sp.p: Well, my Lord—no doubt we shall have sport.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Methinks I shall not sport to-day—dis
miss thy followers awhile—I would confer with thee in private.

sp.speaker: Montauban.
sp.p: How shall your vassal repay this condescension?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Thou know'st Annette, I think, Con
stantia's woman.

sp.speaker: Montauban.
sp.p: I do, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And toy'st with her occasionally?

sp.speaker: Montauban.
sp.p: The damsel has charms, and I admire them, nothing more.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I do not mean to chide thee, gentle Montauban, nor thwart thy amorous pursuits— they may, perchance, enable thee to do me service.

sp.speaker: Montauban.
sp.p: O! Let me fly to execute your commands.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Then, thus it is. I have reason to sus
pect that Constantia holds secret correspondence with Carlos, my avowed, and mortal foe; the man who in life's childish, thoughtless hour, stole my wife's affections; for whose sake she shun'd my embraces, and notwithstanding her father forced her to be mine, with-held from me a husband's lawful rights, and died the sullen vestal she had lived.

sp.speaker: Montauban.
sp.p: You astonish me, my Lord—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Exert thy influence with this forward waiting woman; caress, cajole, do any thing thou canst to discover, if possible, these dark proceed
ings; for know, thy master's peace, his fame, his honor, nay, his life, may be at stake.

sp.speaker: Montauban.
sp.p: Forbid it Heaven!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Hast thou seen Bernardo, my trusty Steward lately?

sp.speaker: Montauban.
sp.p: Not these two days as I think—he seemed wrapt up in thought, and deeply pensive.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Did he so? I do not wonder at it; for indeed, I dread his presence. aside He has done me signal service, and I mean, as suits my charac
ter and station, to give him due reward.

sp.speaker: Montauban.
sp.p: Your Lordship's ever bountiful and good.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
I thought to have met him here—he will not be tardy to attend—I tremble at the inter
view—yet how avoid it—it shall be so aside, tho' Bernardo is deserving of my warmest gratitude,
yet the load of obligation bears so hard upon my nature, I cannot, will not see him face to face, till opportunity afford him ample recompence.

sp.speaker: Montauban.
sp.p: Such ever is the case with noble minds!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Do thou go forward—meet him on the way—give him this ring, as earnest of my friend
ship—tell him we shall meet anon—meanwhile he'll rest assured, my favour shall go hand in hand with his desert to latest life—haste thee, good Montauban.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Right glad I am this meeting is awhile delay'd; for tho' I have gone too far to recede, tho' injured pride, and wounded honor, demand from the offender due expiation; and though I am certain Bernardo has used every pre
caution to secure us from discovery, yet such are the weak workings of my mind, there is a some
thing which I cannot shake off, that makes me shudder at the thought of seeing him.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Pardon me, Count Montoni, if I thus intrude upon your privacy, and dare to interrupt your progress.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Ha! My detested rival. aside I see you dare invade the privilege of decorum, and in
trude upon me like a lawless robber.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
Spare your opprobrious epithet—it re
coils upon yourself—who wa'st that robb'd me of my heart's best joy? The lov'd companion of my early years—the allotted partner of my future life? Who was't that basely practised on a timid female, and in conjunction with a sordid parent, led her
to pronounce unwilling vows, and meanly triumphed o'er a forced consent?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
I scorn your imputation, and despise your vanity; thus idle coxcombs, when their schemes are baffled, and the light froth that flat
ters giddy girls, are in more ripen'd years seen through and slighted, they know not how to bear their humbled pride, but fly to falsehood and abuse for shelter.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Infamous evasion!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Go—learn to check this habit of con
ceit; learn to endure the freaks of female minds; and condescend to think, the gallant Carlos, tho' in the zenith of his youth's career, may some
times suffer from a jilting mistress, while men, with less desert, may prove more fortunate.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
Your levity, Count Montoni, is con
temptible, and your insinuation ungenerous as unjust—did I not, soon as I heard the gentle maid had yielded to your solicitation, and, as I then thought, from worldly motives, abandoned the heart she once had deigned to prize; did I not tear myself from my friends, my family, my home, quit the fond scenes where I had been so blest, and with a bosom bleeding at every pore, leave you to the uninterrupted enjoyment of your nuptial happiness?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Why then return to brave me unpro
voked, and interrupt domestic grief? My wife is now no more; you can no longer plume your
self upon her favour, or attack the sacred honor of a husband.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Heaven grant me patience! Must I then repeat the wrongs thou hast done me, and sting thy hardened bosom with reproach?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Go on—I'm proof against a ruffian's foul invective.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Draw then, and with thy sword defend, what. with thy tongue thou can'st not.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Tis well I am prepar'd, else had thy murderous intent been gratified.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Base slanderer! But words are useless, I come not to remonstrate, but to punish.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Have at thee then, assassin, as thou art!

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: What do I see? My Lord—my Lord—is this the method to secure your wishes?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Bernardo! sinks his sword Then I must pause—no power on earth but thee could stay my arm.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: I see you are now protected; but mark me, Count; my justice shall not sleep till treachery like thine, feel the resentment it deserves.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Take my defiance with thee. Bernardo, thou art welcome! Indeed thou art. I did not think we should have met so soon.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: Not so soon, my Lord! I came hither by your own appointment.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: True; I sent a message to thee, by Montauban, but no matter—this rencontre has determined me—we have no time to lose—I had some compunction; but now rage and jealousy resume their sway.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p:
Let them not transport you too far—
we have hitherto proceeded with discretion; but caution still is necessary.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
The funeral at Palermo will lull sus
picion.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: No doubt, my Lord, it will—but this intruder, Carlos, must be guarded against.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Vile miscreant! His officious return has fixed my wavering resolution, and nerv'd my trembling hand—to-night, at the castle let us meet.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: We will, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Provide thee a torch—a spade—the dagger shall be mine.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: I shall not fail.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
My trusty Ber
nardo, take this casket, it contains jewels that be
longed to—what shall I term her? They now are yours—I am resolved—Oh love! what art thou to revenge!

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: A Room in FRACTIOSO's House—Large door in back Scene—Large window likewise, with dressing table, &c. &c. under it.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Hah! What—when—how—a tall, raw boned fellow, you say, will come into my house, whether I will or no.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Yes; and will see my young Lady, whether you will or no, and will shake you by the fist, whether you will or no.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: And he shall feel my fist too, if he dare incroach upon my premises.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p:
So I told him; but it signified no
thing—Says I, my Master, though a sweet-tempered, sweet-spoken, good kind of a good-looking old gentleman—

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Pooh! What signifies all this foolery?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Not much, indeed, for he would not believe a syllable.—What then, says I, I suppose you think he is a little four-faced, cross-grained, peevish, pettish, surly, avaricious—

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Hold your larum, do, Mrs. Minx, and come to the point at once.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Well. isn't this coming to the point at once.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p:
You say he has something to com
municate—What sort of a person is he?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: He looks like a servant.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Ay, an humble servant, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p:
Humble indeed! I never saw a sau
cier fellow since I was born; he treats me with no more respect, than if I had been his equal.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: You are not his inferior in pertness, that I can warrant—Where is he all this time?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Below in the pantry, stuffing himself with a brace of the best partridges in the whole latder.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p:
Ha! what—devouring my proper
ty—Run, Annette, fetch him before me this in
stant. Exit Annette. Partridges forsooth! Zounds! he's the most im
pudent marauder I ever knew—to plunder the garrison, before a parley can take place.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: Dear Sir, what is the matter? Has any thing happened to disconcert you?

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Any thing! Yes! every thing—I am vexed—teized—threatened—eat up alive.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: Mercy on me! who can have done all this?

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Who? A man—and he would do as much for you, if he could get at you.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: A man, pray dont be alarm'd on my account, I'll face the danger.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: No doubt you would—You have face enough for any thing—I dare say he'd like a young chicken as well as a partridge—but I'll take care to damp his appetite—Oh! here he comes—Do you, Constantia, stand at that end of the room.

div.stage: Enter ANNETTE, and VALOURY gnawing a bone, and walking up to FRACTIOSO in an impudent manner.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: I never tasted a better bird in all my life.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Keep your distance, fellow.

div.stage: Walking from him, and putting Constantia away.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: What, you are the Lord of the Manor, I presume—Do you want a Game-keeper?

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: I'll soon let you know what you want—A Magistrate.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: Oh! oh! You're a Magistrate, are you?—Pray lend me your arm—I love to have Justice on my side.

div.stage: Takes him by the arm, and walks with him forcibly near Constantia.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p:
Why, you audacious varlet, would you assault my person, after having stolen my pro
perty?

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, you quite mistake me; I come to protect your person and property too— There are other people waiting to steal it—You know Signor Carlos?

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Ha! Who—Carlos? Well—what of him?

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: Please to dismiss the Lady of the Bed Chamber.—I only speak to principals in office—always mute before underlings.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Annette retire! And do you hear, let us have none of your listening tricks.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: I listen! I'm sure there's nothing that underlings need stay for; for I fancy I leave both knave and fool behind me.

div.stage: Valoury shews the letter to Constantia as soon as she is gone, so as not to be seen by Fractioso.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: Now, Sir, let us draw near to him, that we may not be over-heard.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Keep away child—Why shou'd we fear being over-heard—Come, sirrah, what have you to tell us?

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.stage: trying in vain to give the letter
sp.p: Signor Carlos, you must know, is—is—

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: What the devil is he? Have you got a pain in your shoulders, that you can't keep your arms still?

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: He is a great friend to one Hilario.

sp.speaker: Constantia
sp.p: Hilario! said you What of him?

sp.speaker: Fractioso
sp.p:
That's no business of yours—Do you presume to make en
quiries after a fellow not worth a dollar—the greatest coxcomb in all Messina.

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p:
And the most impudent dog in all Italy—he once gave me such a slap on the shoul
der.

div.stage:
Slaps Fractioso rudely on the shoulder, and as he turns to resent it, passes the letter to Constan
tia on the opposite side, as he turns.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Why, rascal, scoundrel—how dare you treat me with such familiarity?

sp.speaker: Valoury.
sp.p: I ask pardon! It's a way I have, I only meant to enforce my argument—but I have done—my errand is completed—mute as if your Honour was an underling.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p:
Get out of my house, you impu
dent ragamuffin! This fellow's coming here, had certainly more meaning in it, than I have been able to discover. aside. This is all your doing, Madam Headstrong—One daughter had the per
verseness to die on purpose to plague me, and you seem determined to live on the same system.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: O! Sir, think on my poor sister's hard fate; let that be a lesson to you. Had she married the man of her choice, she might now have been alive to thank you for it.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: The man of her choice! What, that pauper, Carlos, the intimate friend of the prating puppy, Hilario, that you would throw yourself away upon. But I'll take care to prevent it— To-day you shall be lock'd up, and to-morrow sent away to a nunnery.—Annette! Annette!
Where is the key of this apartment?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: In my pocket, Sir,

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Then take it out of your pocket, Ma'am, for I mean to put it into mine.

sp.speaker: Annette
sp.p: Lord, Sir! its fastened to a great swinging bunch—I dont think I shall be able to got it off.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Then open the door with it on— for I am determined to keep my daughter under lock and key.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Not in that room, I hope, Sir; for they say, since poor Madam Julia's death, evil spirits have walked there.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Evil tongues have talked there, more likely—Give me the key directly.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: I must change my ground, aside. To be sure, Sir, here it is. fumbling to get the key off If a young Lady will be obstropolous, why, she ought to be locked up.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: What, are you against me too?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: 'Tis every one's duty to be against you, when you run headlong to destruction. Shall I open the door, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Ay, do, child: I see you are a good, sensible girl, and more discreet than I thought you.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: The very words my grandmother used to make use of: poor old woman! Your honor always puts me in mind of her. trying the key. Fecks! I believe the key-hole is stopt up.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Stopt is it? Well, go and look for something to clear it—You'll find a file, Annette, in the breakfast chamber.—No—now I think of it, I'll go myself, for the tea-chest was left open, I believe, and there's no trusting a waiting woman within the scent of souchong.—Take care of your young Lady till I return.

div.stage: Exit, looking back all the way.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: I believe I can open the door now; Miss Constantia, will you take a peep at your prison?

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: Are you really what you seem, Annette?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: I follow the way of the world, ma'am; but dont mind a little confinement, it's only a prelude to matrimony—look in, and see if there are any spirits, Opens the door, and HILARIO comes out in a travelling cap.—CONSTANTIA screams.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Am I so frightful then, my dearest Constantia! Does this travelling equipage make me look like an hobgoblin?

sp.speaker: Constantia
sp.p: In the name of wonder when did you arrive?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
Not an hour ago—I passed thro' Italy on a gallop—crossed the bay in a storm, landed at the quay in a whirlwind, and flew like lightn
ing to visit my adorable, without waiting for my toilette, as you see; though many a trim barber eyed me wishfully as I scoured along the street, as who should say, "would I might take your worship by the nose!"

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: But how, Hilario, did you gain admittance?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: By the assistance of this, my better angel; she that pretended to take your father's part.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Yes, Ma'am; I always take the blind side, and so I'll fasten the door on the inside.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: But, Hilario, my friend, it will be impossible for you to continue here.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: But, Constantia, my love, it will be impossible for me to continue any where else.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: Will you listen to me?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
For ever, so you don't desire me to leave you; after having scampered across the Con
tinent
like a greyhound, it were hard to be turned out like a mongrel; besides it would be so ungrateful to your indulgent papa, who has thus kindly left us together.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: Mark what poor Carlos writes, reads "I am returned to Messina, for the sole purpose of avenging my Julia's death—should you see Hilario, tell him I am desperate, and may stand in need of his assistance."

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: A very pretty summons! Because he's desperate, he supposes I must be mad; and you, my Constantia, in return for the hole you have made in my heart, want to have a bullet popt thro' my noddle.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: Unkind Hilario! You know the sincerity of my character; though fully tinctured with my sex's levity, I am above the little artifices which they generally adopt—notwithstanding your eccentricities, I am convinced of the goodness of your nature, and believe me, it possesses all my esteem.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
For that dear confession, let me but touch the tip of the nail of your fore-finger, kiss
ing her hand, and command me all over the world.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: Fly then to your friend—conjure him to relinquish his designs—tell him my sister's wrongs are buried with her in the grave; and say, his interference may renew our sorrows; never can redress them.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
I fly at your desire going to the door but hold—I believe I must fly through the key-hole, for Daddy Cautious has double lock'd the
prison. noise-without Zounds! somebody is at the door.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Constantia! Annette!.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: As I live, it is the old one again! What shall we do? If you return into the other room, he'll search it, and we must let him into this—for heaven's sake, Sir, get up the chimney, or out of the window.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Then another old one, that you may have heard of, must assist me—do you think I can climb like a squirrel, or fall upon my legs like a cat?

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Annette, open the door.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Do as he tells you, and rely upon me; if I can't tumble out of window, I can tumble in, which will be a much safer experiment; only prepare yourselves with a good scream to honor my entree.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Annette, I tell you, open the door.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Coming, Sir—my Lady and I have been taking a little nap.

div.stage: Hilario opens the window, then puts his leg out, as if mounted on a ladder, affecting drunkenness, and speaking to persons in the street.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Take away the ladder, my boys—I have done with you.
sp.stage: Annette opens the bolt of the door, and just as Fractioso enters, Hilario tumbles from the window into the room, oversetting the dressing table, &c.
sp.p:
Here I am old trusty!—I was deter
mined to make you a visit, and finding your doors lock'd against me, I made bold to come in at the window.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: That wicked dog, Hilario! Oh, you villain! I'll have you laid by the heels, that I will.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: That's right, father, take care of my heels—you see I have taken care of my head already.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: You're a house-breaker—you want to plunder my property, and run away with my child.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Damn your property—I'll have none of it; and as for your sweet child, I adore her— and you too, old surly—I'll adore you too.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Help! Help! He will murder me, and ruin the women. Constantia, why don't you run for assistance?

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, there's no occasion to be in such a panic—it's only a drunken frolic— I dare say the gentleman will do us no harm.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: I dare say you'll think it no harm, let the gentleman do what he will.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Right, Sir—there your honour put me in mind of my poor old grandmother again.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: And this is the fellow you wou'd give me for a son-in-law?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Yes, I am he, Holofernes—I am the Very fellow—Come, give us your blessing, old boy, and who knows, but in good time, you may have a supply of young ones.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Give you my blessing? Give you a halter! Get out of my house, this instant, if you don't wish to be hanged up in the court-yard.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p:
Pray, Sir, be so kind as to walk down stairs—no doubt you have friends
in the neighbourhood, who may be uneasy at your stay—Pray begone.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
I am off—much adored nymph—dam
sel of divinity—I'll do what you desire—steady, steady to my promise—farewell, old Coffer.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Away with you, you filthy sot.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.stage: stopping his mouth with his hand
sp.p: Hold —hold—no words—I'll tell you a story.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: I dare say you will—a thousand. But leave my house, and never let me see your face again.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: You sha'n't—you sha'n't see my face, old Cormorant; for I'll come back in a mask, and we'll have some fun, my man of merriment, we will. Harkee! Do you know me? imitating a masquerade character I am son-in-law to little Fractie, the justice grinder, as cross-gained a crab as any in all Messina. He possesses more ducats than I do doits, and yet thinks as much of burning an inch of candle, as I shou'd of illuminating the whole city. Nevertheless I'll hug the old rogue, that I will—I'll hug him into good humour.

div.stage: Goes to embrace Fractioso, who roars out and drives him off.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p:
Murder! I shall be suffocated— Help to turn him out returns and adjusts himself Mercy on me! There is no security for one, either at home or abroad—All the bolts in the world can't keep a forward girl in the house, or hanker
ing fellow out of it.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p:
Dear papa, you do not, indeed you do not pursue the right method to secure my duty, or your own peace. Would parents treat their children as friends, instead of keeping them at a severe distance, the social communication of each
other's sentiments, would enable one party to give better advice, and induce the other more readily to accept it.

sp.speaker: Anentte.
sp.l: Lock and key—no hold can be—

sp.speaker: Fractioso,
sp.l: Still my shoulders feel the blow.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: The outside of an old Castle with large gates closed, a turret door is visible in the interior of the Castle—a hole in the wall, that appears to lead to a subterraneous passage—The whole wears an appearance of great antiquity and ruins.
Enter CLODDY with a quantity of hares, patridges, &c.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p:
Well done, Cloddy! Thee didsn't lay thy snares last night for nothing—By the dickens, here's as pretty a bunch of preserved property as any justice would wish to see at his table; and a
pretty round sum it will bring me, when I ha' got it safe housed—for our old rich citizens do so like a tit-bit, especially when it is prohibited—and why should they not? They call me a poacher— mayhap, so I be—what then—so be other people. Its my belief as how its a pretty general trade.

lg.l: Every scheme by day or night
Friends to trap, the wit will try,
He tips the wink, and cocks his eye,
And while he looks so woundy sly
Makes game, e'en of his brother.
See Miss and Madam lay their snares,
While Miss in dancing, reels and drolls,
With a hitch, and capering itch,

sp.p: Od so! Here's somebody coming! I must run into my old hiding place yonder—that hole under the Castle wall—it has used to be a rare snug place; but o' late I ha' heard so many strange noises near about, I fear there be other people hiding as well as myself—rabbit it, here they come!

div.stage: Retreats into a hole under the wall.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
So, my poor friend, after the father had generously locked you into his daughter's apart
ment—he cooly turned you neck and heels out of his own street door.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
Faith, something very like it; or, not
withstanding my attachment to your person, my love for another person's person, would have made me a truant to friendship.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Impossible!

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Impossible is it, that a man should prefer being safe in a warm house, playing bo-peep with the bright eyes of his mistress, to scampering across a cold country for a game at pistols with his friend's rival?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Notwithstanding your pleasantry, I am convinced you would go a great way to serve me.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
Yes, and not a little way to serve myself—your kindnesses to me, and our early
friendship will, I trust, never be forgotten—you certainly stand second—that is, after the ladies, in my account—but I myself, am at the top of the page, and you know its the fashion now, to take care of number One.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: True my friend; and number One is at present tolerably secure—I have already had a rencontre with this dread adversary.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Already! I hope you are not wounded?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Sorely.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Bless me, Carlos! Where is it?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
In the heart, Hilario—deep—incur
able—a surgeon's skilful hand may ease the poniard's stroke—time's healing finger is ineffec
tual here.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: I am sorry for it. How much kinder the old greybeard is to me—as he totters round me with a grin, I whip his scythe from his hand, and cut off my sorrows in the middle.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Enviable vivacity! Had not relendess fortune mark'd me for the child of woe, I might have shared in all your chearfulness.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: My dear friend, take comfort—let us return to the city—these desolate old ruins don't seem to promise much entertainment— they've made me grave already.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: To me the world is all a void—Julia! my once destined Julia's lost for ever! As they go out, a bell tolls in the Castle. Whence came that dismal sound?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: From that dismal castle I suppose—let us begone—the toll of a bell always makes me nervous.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: I thought this dreary spot had been uninhabited—who could have occasioned it?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Who? Gaffer Belzebub, to be sure— who the devil else would live in such a place—I shall retire—he's not fit company for me.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Perhaps it is some person in distress— some lonely hermit, sinking beneath the pressure of disease!

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
Or, perhaps, some robber, who hav
ing tenderly murdered the lonely hermit, kindly resolves to give him christian burial.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Again—I am resolved to see further into this business.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: And I am determined to remain totally in the dark—Carlos, I'm off.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Will you leave me Hilario? Can you desert your friend?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
What did you say? Desert you— never—I may be at times, a little apprehensive, but I never can forsake my friend—was the whole court of Lucifer armed against my Carlos, dam'me but I'd have a tustle with some of the cloven black
legs.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Come then—suppose we try whether these antique gates will yield to our attack.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Move on—if the worst comes to the worst, it will be only bringing an old house about our ears—it won't do—old Ebony has fastened them with his own claw.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.stage: going towards the place where Cloddy is
sp.p: Let us search narrowly round the mouldering walls; time may, perhaps, have made some opening in them a light appears Softly—dost: thou observe a light in yonder turret?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
A light! To be sure I did—
the devils are at work—I think we had better leave them to themselves.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Mark! It moves along—now it disappears.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: I'm glad of it—we've seen enough— however, don't be afraid—I'll stick close by you.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Here is actually a hole, seemingly under the wall; who knows but it may afford a passage into the castle—Heavens! something living is concealed in it.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Be upon your guard, Carlos—don't venture in—it may be a wolf, or a tiger.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Then it must be a man tiger. However, be it what it may, I'll drag it forth—Shew thyself, fellow, and say, what brings thee here?

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p:
Brings me here! Why, ise only fetch
ing a walk.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Fetching a walk! What, in a hole in the wall? Zounds! this is the most impudent fetch I ever heard of.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: No trifling, sirrah! Tell us who that castle belongs to?

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Nan!

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Blockhead! does any one reside in that castle?

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Reside! what be that?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Does any body live there? Answer this minute, or it shall be your last.

sp.speaker: Cloddy
sp.p:
O lud! O lud! Noa. No
body lives there but the rooks and ravens. To be sure they ha'had some visitors lately, and by their cawing and croaking, I dont think they much like their company.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: What company are you talking of?

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p:
Why, spirits and hobgoblins, I be
lieve; for I never heard such shrieking and squeaking in all my born days.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Shrieking and squeaking! Hadn't we better get more assistance, Carlos?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: What avails human assistance, if we are to encounter supernatural foes? Did you ever see, as well as hear, any thing extraordinary?

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Yes, one night, when I was taking a walk.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: What, walking again, friend? Well, what did you see?

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p:
Why, I feed a light in the South tower, and soon after, a sort of a kind of an ap
parition appeared, and when I cried out, it called me fool.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Ay, claim'd relationship.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: What was it like?

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: There—look there it be again!

div.stage: A person with a dark lanthorn, muffled up, looks out from a turret-window, and then retires, shutting the window.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
Something mysterious is certainly go
ing on—I am determined to unravel it.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
I hate mysteries confoundedly. How
ever, I dont speak because I want to flinch—But it is so ill bred to pry into family secrets.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Somebody is approaching—We have no time to lose.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Its Master Montauban, with the sportsmen—I must be off.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Off, fellow!—for what reason? who are you?

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: I be Cloddy, own brother to sister Annette, and she be the same to me.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: How! brother to my Guardian-angel —Come to my arms, my ally from the hole in the wall—Annette assisted me, and therefore you and I will fetch a walk together.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Wounds! An'you be sister's friend, I'll do any thing you like; and if you want to peep into that old castle, I believe I can shew you a way under the wall; but you must stoop very low, and, mayhap, creep upon all-fours.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
No matter—point out the path—no
thing can deter us. Horns again. Time presses— away—away.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: I wish, with all my soul, we were fifty leagues away from this place.

div.stage: Exit thro' the hole in the wall.

lg.head: GLEE.
lg.l: What shall he have who sported best?
A shout of joy from all the rest—
The honest heart, no doubts will start;
But join the strain before we part;
The Horn, the Horn, the echoing Horn,
Shall rouse the Sportsmen ev'ry morn;
On you the palm will fall, Sir;
No, not on one, but all, Sir;
Now sends us all content away.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage:
An old room, hung with antique, tattered tape
stry—two doors exactly alike in the back scene, covered with the same tapestry—A window over them, the stage to be a little darken'd.

Enter the COUNT, muffled in a cloak, and BER
NARDO.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
At length, my friend, the hour of retri
bution comes; and love insulted, claims its sacri
fice—the time, the place, occasion—all conspire, while secrecy secures revenge.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: Would I could say ought to stay your purpose!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Impossible! 'tis now too late—Is not this favour'd rival come to vaunt his valour? Shall we restore the idol of his panting heart, and be ourselves, the victims of his triumph?

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: Never my lord—her destiny is fix'd.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Yet, spite of the rage which fires an injur'd husband's breast, resisted pity will at times intrude—fear too, appals, and dread remorse— the very figures fashion'd in these antient hang
ings, with ghastly eye-ball seem to frown upon us.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: Weak imagery of the brain, which quick decision must efface—trust me, my Lord, we have little leisure to deliberate.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What mean'st thou, Bernardo?

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p:
Not an hour ago, waiting, as is my duty, for your Lordship's presence; a deep ton'd
bell, fixed unknown to me, in the interior of the Castle, was on a sudden by our mourner sounded.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p:
At first I thought 'twas fancy; but being repeated, I flew to trace the cause, and in
stant cut the rope.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Twas well.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: Soon after, the outward gates were by rude hands attempted to be forced.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Thou alarm'st me—

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: With speed I mounted to the turret, and descried some strangers in close conference.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Didst thou know them?

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: The day declining, prevented more discovery—The sportsmen returning from the field forced them to retire.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Who could they be? No matter—ap
prehension will but prompt our purpose—her doom's inevitable—but then—the remains.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: All is prepared—the coffin is at hand.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
So ready, Bernardo—Yet, wherefore delay—danger may follow—bring hither the crow, the fatal dagger too—I left it in the portal, my hand refuses—can I be the assassin? Stay awhile—yet no—begone—fly—give not hor
rid thought a moment's pause.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: I will return, my Lord, as quick as the dark windings of this dreary mansion will permit me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
The night advances fast— wherefore this inward pang, this struggle of na
ture? Come, wounded pride, love slighted, scorn
ed—come suffering honour, aid this weak heart,
and give it manly resolution—hush! was not that a sigh, a deepened sigh? How soon the last must follow, let me seize this solitary interval to take one final look, silent, unobserved—alas! the dim light that glooms around, scarce shews the dismal path.

div.stage:
Enter CARLOS with a dark lanthorn and HIL
LARIO with a broken piece of a shield—they ascend from a cavern.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
Carlos! Carlos! Carlos! softly—you go too fast—thank heaven, at last we have emer
ged from that horrid cavern—zounds! I am as damp as a new newspaper, and as musty as old cheese out of a wine cellar.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
In truth, Hilario, it is somewhat sur
prising, after the extraordinary occurrences with
out the walls of this old castle, we should as yet be able to make no discoveries within; a solemn silence seems to reign around, and nothing, save the hollow murmur of the wind, strikes on the listening ear.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: A murmur of another kind, struck upon my ear.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: You shall hear—but come a little further from that cursed cavern; you know, after having trampt about these diabolical apartments for half an hour together, we agreed to separate at the end of a long gallery, and took different routs.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: We did so—and the distant glimmer of light from this lanthorn, which I found standing on the pavement, led me to the dismal recess where we again met—but proceed—

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: The fact is, that old Ebony has been more attentive to me, than to your worship.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Will you be serious one moment?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Serious! upon my soul I don't think I shall ever be otherwise. I am terrified to death— I cou'd as soon raise the devil as a grin.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Torture me not with suspense—but tell me all.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
That I will, if I can find breath to go thro' with it—first I descended several steps of a dark narrow passage—at the bottom I heard a door open, then the patting of a man's foot, whether cloven or not I can't say—soon after, I saw a light, so I made a pause, and said to myself now dont be frightened, Hilario—now dont trem
ble, my dear fellow, but summon up all your courage, and boldly run away.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Would I had been there instead of you.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Would you had, with all my heart! tho' I defy you to run faster—but in the attempt, I fell plump on my face, and in scrambling to get up, I clawed hold of this broken bit of a shield. There seems something like letters scratch'd upon it.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
Letters, Hilario! Try then, to decy
pher them.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
No, try your
self, I have got such a mumbling in my mouth, and my teeth so chatter, that—

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
Heavens! what's this I see? reads "Julia, wife to the Count of—was forced to this Castle—the marble hall—the dreary vault—Oh pity and remember" drops the shield 'tis the labour of my Julia's
hand, the unavailing record of her hapless fate— Oh my foreboding heart! she has been murdered.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
I'm all over in a cold perspiration, we had better get into the open air—it may save us from a fit of the ague—I feel die quaking al
ready.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
Never will I quit this gloomy edifice, till I discover my poor Julia's sad remains, dread
ful idea!—the mangled relicks of her beauteous form.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Dreadful indeed! who knows but our forms may be mangled in the same manner.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
Was it for this, I left my friends, my home? To abandon the dear object of my earli
est vows, to coward fraud and ruffian violence, Gods! I shall run distracted!

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Be advised, Carlos—let us retire.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: No faithful monitor to warn her unsuspecting youth—no arm to shield her helpless innocence—heh! what noise was that?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: What? the perspiration is coming again.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: It sounded like a groan.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Dear Sir, dont frighten one, more than there is occasion.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Mark me—observe that window—do you not see a light?

div.stage: a light is seen to pass

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: A Li—ght!

sp.speaker: Carlos.

div.stage: Runs out thro' one of the doors in the Scene.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Follow! I'm numb'd, I'm petrified—I have not a limb to stand upon—soft —let me try advances one leg yes, I have put my right foot foremost, no, let me take it back again. retreats a little Thunders again What shall I leave my friend in the lurch? let him grapple with old Ebony by himself? for shame, Hilario! after him, my boy! Goes towards the doors in the Scene, opens one on the right of that where Carlos entered, which discovers a Coffin standing on a bier, with a lamp upon it. Wheugh! I'm dead and buried! a Coffin! shuts door and I dare say the sexton will be here before I can say my pray'rs, mum! here he comes.

div.stage: Enter BERNARDO with a spade and dagger.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: Count! Count!

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: He mistakes me for somebody else.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: Your excellence!

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Its an excellent mistake, however.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: Where are you?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: He—ere.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p:
I have brought the spade and dag
ger as you ordered.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Give them to me.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: You feel cold.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Yes—its so hot.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: Hot! its a dreadful night—but all will soon be over. I'll enter the recess the back way, and lead the victim down the steps into the marble hall—'tis yours to give the blow.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: I will, I will.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: Till then farewell!

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.stage: the spade in one hand, the dagger in the other
sp.p: Give the blow! gad, if I dont take great care I shall get the blow. I shiver from head to heel like a top-sail in a storm. This murder-loving villian has kindly indulged me with two instruments, one to kill myself with, and the other to dig my own grave.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Bernardo why do you loiter so? Is this a time for delay? what, silent; do you shrink at last? Give me the means—I'll do the rest myself, faithless coward!

div.stage: Snatches the dagger and goes out.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
Faithless coward! aye so it seems, else shou'd I leave poor Carlos to battle with these two butchers alone? No by heaven! Thunder aye, growl on, I'll extricate my friend or perish with him opens door where Carlos went out bless me, how dark! would I had half a do
zen lacqueys at my back with a flambeau in each hand. If a man must be executed, I think the more parade the better.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage:
A large antique hall, with black marble pillars on each side, distant from the wings—an open arch at the back, dis
covering a stone stair-case, leading from an upper appart
ment.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
What could Bernardo mean? He seem'd fix'd and motionless. He will not sure be
tray
me— impossible a noise of opening locks hark! the door opens—he leads her down—the dreadful scene approaches—I'll conceal myself awhile.

div.stage:
Bernardo with a lighted torch in his hand, leads Julia down the stair-case into the mar
ble hall.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: My duty is discharg'd—lady, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh Bernardo! do not leave me thus— tho' in the lone recess, where I have been so long confined, without one succouring friend to cheer my solitude, tho' when you daily brought my scanty pittance, a gloomy silence mark'd your short'ned stay; now, I conjure you, grant my last request, ere suffering nature sink to long oblivion— say, why am I now brought sorth?

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: I but obey the mandate of my lord, your husband.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: My husband! say my tyrant, murderer.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: I must not listen to such epithets.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p:
Did he not, under pretence of riding for my health, entice me to this sequestered spot, attended only by yourself? Did he not, on a sud
den, force me from my horse, drag me thro' various dark apartments, and lodge me in that vaulted room, from whence you now have led me?

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: Lady, he is here.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh stay—protect me—do not abandon a poor helpless female, to such detested hands.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
'Tis well, Madam—I see your haughty spirit still con
tinues—softness might have subdued my feeble
nature—and woman's tears, might have produ
ced a womanish compassion.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Fear not, ferocious man—no tears can soften thy obdurate heart, nor will compassion find a votary there.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Once again, I'll deign to ask what punishment you think your conduct merits.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p:
Talk'st thou of conduct! can'st thou mention wrongs? Thou who hast injured me be
yond description—stabbed my fair fame; robbed me of health, and cut me off from every hope in life.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Thyself alone, hath wrought thy own undoing—hath caused the woes you have already borne—the pangs you yet must suffer—am I not thy husband?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p:
Oh, profane not thus the sacred appel
lation—a husband! honor'd name! wooes the soft virgin in the morn of life—wooes, if her heart be free, and fairly wins, but thou—

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Well Madam! what of me?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p:
To gratify a base, unworthy passion— knowing my soul was wedded to another, left no dishonourable means untried, to force a wretched maid, heart-broken, to your arms—had not dis
gusted nature made me shun thee.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Call it not nature, but adulterous love— a wanton flame excited by another—an outcast, rejected by your parent.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Unhappy parent! who, misled by treachery, and lured by gain, hath doom'd his child to misery and death.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Art thou then prepared?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p:
If innocence and purity of mind be pre
paration, then am I ready. If, with a heart sus
ceptible
of every soft emotion, to have lavished all the tenderness of growing years, on one whom I am taught to think unworthy, whilst a hated tyrant holds me at his disposal, be the height of human woe, then is the grave my only refuge.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: To make that grave more welcome— know, ill-fated fair, thy minion was not false!

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Not false! not wedded to another.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
No—devoted but to thee, he wan
ders o'er the earth, a wretched exile.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: You have pierced me to the soul—now draw thy murderous steel—thou can'st not wound me more.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: To save you from a disgraceful union, I plann'd this honest artifice—to save myself from shame, I brought you hither—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: To save thy own coward heart.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Coward! be ad
vis'd—desist—'twere fatal to go on.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Yes, coward—to glut thyself in a weak woman's blood; alone—defenceless—lost to every human being—none to protect—none to avenge her death—else had the valiant youth, whom thou, at distance, darest calumniate, awed thy dastard spirit with a frown.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: 'Tis too much— since thou wilt provoke.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Strike, monster, strike—for with my latest breath, I will adore his virtues, and execrate thy baseness.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Then breathe thy last.

div.stage: Enter CARLOS. Julia faints in his arms.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Hold—ruffian!—murderer!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Confusion! he here! What ho! Bernardo.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
Revive, my Julia! Let me not again lose you, thus unexpectedly re
stored.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh! save me from that tyrant!

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Be not alarm'd, my angel—recall your scatter'd spirits—'tis your Carlos, who implores.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Carlos! My long lost, my unhappy friend!—Oh, my distracted thoughts! by what magic are you here?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: By that, which from the first moment I beheld you, influenced all my actions—by the magic of your blooming graces, the memory of our endearments, the misery of our separation, the dreadful uncertainty of your fate.—

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Carlos! I have been sadly used— Anguish and distress have been my portion, since you left me.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Did I leave you, Julia?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p:
Oh no! Julia deserted you—forsook the dear possessor of her first affections—But, tho' not yours, believe me, I have never been ano
ther's.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: How! Are you not wife to the Count? May I once more press you to this faithful bosom?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Desist—it must not be— Time will unravel all—O Carlos! feel for your devoted Julia—And the more you hear of my misfortunes, the more you will respect them— Had I not believed you false, a parent's threat, a father's supplication, had been equally in vain.

div.stage: Enter HILARIO—BERNARDO's sword in his hand.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Dam'me, how I peppered him! the scoundrel—hah! my honored Lady Julia—he told me you was alive—let me thus speak my joy.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Where have you been, my friend?— to whom doth that sword belong?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
To one of the butchers, to be sure— I have got him snug in a closet, and you may peep at him thro' the iron bars, as you would at a curiosity—I'll have him shewn for a sight—Oh Carlos! had you seen my courage—I wanted no
thing but a live lady to animate me—for the moment I heard how it was, Madam—I fought like a lion.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: You deserve every thing.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: I drove him down a stair-case—whisk'd him thro' a trap-door—dragg'd him over the dusty rubbish—caged him—and here I am with his trophy—but what's become of the other butcher?

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: Fled, like a guilty coward—but I'll pursue him thro' the world.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
And so will I, into the next—Wheugh! my hand is in, and I could fight a legion of Bel
zebubs.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p:
Oh, my friends! let me conjure you to proceed no further—leave the wretch to the re
proaches of a guilty conscience, to the rage of disappointed malice—Carlos you have saved my life, now protect my fame—conduct me to my father's house—there alone, my harrass'd mind can be at peace.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
Forgive the impetuosity of a man, torn
with contending passions—agitated at once by love, resentment, by hope, and by despair—your fame has ever been dearer to me than my own— let us then, quit this scene of horror, and restore my injur'd Julia to her paternal roof.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p:
Attempt not, Carlos, to accompany me home—you know how much my father is in
censed against you—should we be seen together, 'twill give such colour to the Count's calumny, as may prove injurious to us both—for the whole story will so crowd upon his mind—

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
Egad, so it will—then the tables may be turn'd upon us, and Ebony make us appear as black as himself—now, leave every thing to me— Fractioso and all—I am the man for the old one —if Lady Julia will trust herself to my care, I'll undertake to convey her, unseen, to the apart
ment of her sister, my adored Constantia; and then we can manage her return to life with all pro
per decorum.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Lead on.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p:
Must we then part so soon? Oh Julia, form'd for the enjoyment of social tenderness, my heart is doom'd to suffer unceasing disappoint
ment. At least, let me conduct you safely thro' the arched vaults, and narrow passages, that fill this melancholy pile—then will I pursue the guilty Count, and consign him to the vengeance of of
fended laws.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Take with thee, Carlos, all the love I dare to offer, every anxious with I freely can bestow.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
And as you don't want any of my courage, I'll take it all with me, to guard my precious charge—and then, fire and tow! let me
see who will dare to come within arm's length of us.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: What is to be done with the owner of your trophy there?

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
Ay, the rascal in the pound—we must take him with us, and secure his evidence, by pro
mise of pardon.

sp.speaker: Carlos.
sp.p: But notwithstanding your courage, Hilario, 'twill be as prudent to have some officers of justice to assist us.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p:
Certainly—for the most dauntless spi
rit may be sometimes seized with a cold perspi
ration—but never mind—move on—I'll lead the way brandishing his sword follow close, if you please tho', and we shall sooner be out of this cursed old den of Philistines.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p:
Where can my young Lady be gone? I have search'd for her all over the house—she must certainly have gone abroad—and she may thank me for the opportunity—how astonish'd she will be, when she knows what I have overheard —I must say, my talent for listening has been of great service to me in life, and has help'd me to un
ravel a number of mysteries.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: A sweet scented courtier once gave me a kiss,
And promised me mountains, if I would be his,
But soon I found courtiers were callous to shame,
And mountains and mole-hills with them were the same.

sp.p: For that very night, when I was at my favourite amusement, listening, I heard a rustling of silks upon the stair-case, there was my spark making love to my Lady's maid, rigged out in an old cast off, of her mistresses: so,—

lg.l: Soon I found courtiers were callous, &c.

lg.head: II.
lg.l: A widow, whose tears were unceasingly shed,
For her spouse, her protector, her all, that was dead;
Made me wonder the dame should such sorrow survive,
Till I found that she had a kind cousin alive.

sp.p: For calling one day, with some bombazeen to renew her weeds with, I overheard a parley in the back drawing room, "come widow, don't carry on this farce any longer, its troublesome to be squeezing out tears from morning to night, marry me at once, you know my merit—I managed your late husband's business the last five years of his life."

lg.l: No longer I wonder'd the dame should survive,
When I found that she had a kind cousin alive.

lg.head: III.
lg.l: A maiden of sixty, so pure and so prim,
As tall as a maypole, and nearly as slim;
Protested her pleasures in life were all o'er,
At length I perceived she'd one comfort in store.

sp.p:
For being invited to a snug dish of tea and a little scandal, I chanced to go somewhat sooner than I was expected, and passing her chamber I heard the corner cupboard unlock, and the follow
ing soliloquy. "Come to my heart, my best supporter; man, faithless man, has slighted and deceived me, you are the only warm friend I have."

lg.l: So I plainly perceived, tho' laid flat on the floor,
Life still has one comfort for maids of three score.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: Annette, what can have detained Hilario so long?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p:
What can have detained you so long? I have something to tell you of the utmost impor
tance.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: What mean you? For heav'n's sake be explicit—has any thing happened to him?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Yes, Ma'am—to him, and to her, and to me, and to all the world.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p:
If you have any love for me, I con
jure you to shorten the misery of suspence—say, is he dead?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: No Madam—nor is she dead—nor I— nor any body else—we are all come to life again.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: You rave Annette—or do you find delight in torturing your unhappy mistress.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: I torture you, my dear young Lady! I had rather torment a dozen lovers from morning till night, than give you one moment's uneasiness, but I am so confounded, and so overjoyed, and so perplexed, and so—

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: What can be the matter?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Why then, as I hope for one husband at least, I have some reason to think that my Lady Julia is not dead.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: How! My sister alive?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: You shall hear—just now, as I was standing in the passage, thinking of nothing, and peeping, as I now and then do, in a little pocket looking glass, who should whisk by me, but the Count Montoni.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: What of him?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: He look'd alarm'd and confused, and I am convinced he didn't know what he was about.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Because he took no more notice of me, than if I had been the meerest dowdy in all Messina—so I was determined to go and listen at the door of your father's library, where they were lock'd up together.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: At first I heard some muttering about an old Castle, and then the words, "Carlos and murder."

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: "Carlos and murder!" Alas, my poor Hilario, no wonder you are not returned.

sp.speaker: Anette.
sp.p:
Don't be uneasy, Madam—I am cer
tain no mischief has happened; for I heard the old Gentleman exclaim, "Julia not dead, then Carlos must be laid hold of," and so, Ma'am I ran to acquaint you with the news.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: If you love me, Annette, steal softly back again, and try if you can discover any thing further.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: I will, my dear Lady—listening is my forte—and for sounds, shew me who has a finer ear than myself.

sp.speaker: Constantia.
sp.p: My sister still living! Can it be possible? Some dreadful mystery remains to be discovered—oh, Julia, how deplorable must have been your situation.

lg.l: In the cup of female life,
Every draught to maid or wife,
So the cup, of female life,
Bitter is, to maid or wife;

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: A Sea prospect in the vicinity of MESSINA, with a view of SCYLLA and CHARIBDIS—SCYLLA is a rock, with a light-house upon it—CHARIBDIS, a whirlpool below, on which the light is to shine.
Supposed to be late in the evening, and the Stage to be somewhat darkened.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p:
Sure as I'm born, a pretty tight sports
man, something queer is going to happen, by rea
son my right eye did so tickle and itch this morn
ing—and our cat made up such a woundy thick tail, that—but where o' the name o' dickens have I wandered to? Ho! I sees—there be my old friends, Scylla and Charibdis—they say, whoever gets clear o' the first, falls plump down into the latter, that's for certain—if you don't break your head against the rock, you are drowned below in the whirlpool—ah, it's the fame with the women —the moment you get quitten o' one, pop you're laid hold of by another.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Oh brother! My dear brother Cloddy I'm glad I've met you—I'm almost frighten'd out of my wits.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: That's unlucky—because why—you ha' no great deal to spare.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Then I'm a true sister—I take after you—but no matter—I have such wonderful news to tell you.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: It's no more than I expected—I thought our cat's tail did not swell for nothing—what be it?

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Why, I never listen—but I have a way of overhearing, you know.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Yes, I know you have—wounds, here's Scylla and Charibdis both in one—but on with you.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Well—I heard the Count tell my old master, that his daughter Julia, my dear lost lady, was still alive—that the great burial was all a flam —and that she was found secreted in an old castle, under the protection of Signor Carlos, her first lover, who, he says, aided by Constantia, and Hilario, were the authors of the whole contrivance.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p:
Odratten! I don't believe it—I be
lieve that black dog I used to see on the parapet, was the real poacher; he and the Count, depend on't, were the knaves that laid the snares.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p:
So I think—and therefore I have ven
tured abroad this dark night, at my lady's desire, in hopes I may be able to see Madam Julia, who, they say, is still at the castle, and give her intelli
gence of the plots that are carrying on against her at this moment.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Oh! Ho! So then I find your great folks can carry on their plots in the dark, as well as us little ones.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p:
Yes; the old Gentleman, at the insti
gation of the Count, has summoned the city guard to their assistance, and ordered the gallies to row round the light-house, in case Carlos and his friend should put off to sea; for he has resolved this very night to arrest, and convey them to prison. Come with me, brother—there is not a moment to lose.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: No—nor a moment to find neither; for here are the whole posse at our heels, and as I don't much like a prison—why I'll make bold to step behind that tree; and listen, sister, as you do, by way of overhearing.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: And so must I too, by way of security.

div.stage: Enter COUNT, FRACTIOSO, Guards, &c. &c. with torch lights.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p:
Go forward with the lights, I tell you—I can't see an inch before my nose advances This it is to be hauled out at mid
night, when we ought to be snug in our beds.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Consider Sir, the honour of your fami
ly, which must be supported.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p:
So I do, Count—I do con
sider it—but I cant help saying I wish it could be supported in broad day, with a warm sun over our heads—nothing can be so dreadful, as the shriek
ing of owls, and the croaking of frogs, when one must climb battlements, and dive into caverns.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Undoubtedly—and unless fame and property were at stake.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p:
There it is—was it not for one's pro
perty, I should not much care.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Who knows to what lengths the con
spirators may go—detection may make them des
perate.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Zounds! so it may—that rascal, Hilario, is one of the gang, I warrant.—He's a most desperate dog, believe me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: No doubt he is.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p:
That fellow, and his friend Carlos, have been my torment these five years, on and off. They come in at a window to one daughter, and lock another up in a Castle—look ye, Count, I can't say I ever doubted you and now I am con
vinced that Constantia — Carlos — Julia—that damn'd Hilario, and all of them, have joined in a conspiracy to rob and murder us—for if they bring dead people to life, they can soon make live peo
ple dead.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
You know, Signor, that your daugh
ter Julia went to Palermo, at your own request, for change of air; it was not then in my power to attend her—news was brought to us of her de
cease, and funeral honours followed in due course this you are acquainted with—but you know not perhaps, that Carlos's servant, if not himself, was discovered prying about during the solemnity.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Zounds! I'm all over in a conflagration —where is the castle? which is the road? I'll seize them myself—hah! here are some of them—stand back—keep back with the lights—let's listen— mum!

div.stage: Exit guards, and men with lights.
Enter JULIA and HILARIO, followed by BERNARDO, guarded.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Would we were at home! tis a dreary, dismal journey, in the dead of night.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: No doubt you think so—since you have been obliged to separate yourself from poor Carlos.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Did you mind that, Count—I told you I saw thro' the plot— there's no deceiving me.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I dread the meeting with my father— he is so credulous and partial to the Count.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: I know it—but if he won't believe his own eyes, and will persist in persecuting you, do you think I'll stand tamely by—no—as I have brought you from one old tottering fabric, I wont see you entomb'd in another.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: You wont,—you imp—you puppy, wont you?—Count—guards— seize him—he is the wicked one.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: No—seize the Count—there he stands; he is the wicked one. Guards seize Hilario. What are you about?

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: My father!

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p:
Keep off, cockatrice—I see thro' it all—you can't impose upon me, didn't you pre
tend you was dead—put the whole family to the expence of new mourning, and make us cry our eyes out.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Oh my honour'd parent! listen to your child.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Regard her not—false to her husband, will she be just to her parent?

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p:
I wont hear a word—you're an un
grateful
girl, and as low minded as that rascal we have caught you with—you would rather live in an old cellar with Carlos, than in a superb mansion with the noble Count, your husband.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Unhand me, that I may tear that noble monster piece-meal—come forward you penitent tool of authority—you promised, if I wou'd unpound you, to speak the truth?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Speak Bernardo! you can protect me from the slanderer's tongue, but for you I had fal
len by the poignard of that assassin, Carlos, who having stained my honour, wou'd have dyed it deeper with my blood.

sp.speaker: Bernardo.
sp.p: True my lord—but for me, your life had been sacrificed. But for me, your fame would now be destroyed—give me liberty, and I will fully explain the guilt of Carlos, and his vile associates.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Guilt of Carlos! oh Belzebub! that thou should'st suffer mortals thus to outdo thee.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Stop that fellow's mouth, and release Bernardo—I want no further proof—Carlos shall be hang'd, and you sent to the gallies for life.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: What, tie me to an oar!—Is this the way a grandee shou'd treat his future son-in-law.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Will nobody stop that fellow's mouth? You, Madam, shall be convey'd to some remote distance, to try if confinement will restore you to a sense of your duty.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Confinement, alas, has itself no terror for your child—But if nature yet pleads for me in your breast, Oh, let my prison be my father's home—devote me not again, to horror and to death.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p:
What do you mean by being devo
ted? Isn't the Count, your husband, a man of honour—a man of fortune, rank and title?—you would be devoted only to that villian Carlos.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Carlos is not a villain—I'll tell you what—his soul is right honourable, every inch of it, whilst that of the Count is like the old shabby bit of parchment that describes his titles—black, white, narrow, cold, and shrivelled.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Contemptible defamer!

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Here's a fellow! talk to me of a shabby bit of parchment—I that am Vice Legate, Proetor, Nuncio, Viguier, Rota, Scrota, and so forth—away with him to the gallies—away.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p:
On my knees let your un
happy daughter sue to you for justice—tho' doom
ed herself to inevitable destruction, let not her brave deliverer be the victim of his own compas
sionate heart.

sp.speaker: Hilario.
sp.p: Spare yourself the trouble, Ma'am— I have done my duty as becomes the future son-in-law to a grandee—life's an eternal see-saw—now I am a poor galley slave—in a month, perhaps, I may make a cockswain—in another, captain of a squadron, and in a third, Vice Legate, Proetor, Viguier, Nuncio, Rota, Scrota, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Fractioso.
sp.p: Take him away, I tell you, and clap him in irons.

Now Count, we'll go and engage a vessel—mean
while Mountaubon, with some chosen soldiers, shall pursue Carlos—We'll revenge ourselves I warrant—an impudent ragamuffin, to compare me to a shabby bit of parchment—zounds! I'll have his hide so tann'd, that a troop of drummers
may find employment upon it—lead on, torch
bearers!

div.stage: ANNETTE and CLODDY, come from behind trees.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Here's a pretty business! talk of my laying snares! why, no poacher in all Sicily can trap this fox of a Count—odratten it! I should like to unkennel him.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p: Do, my dear Cloddy—think how they've treated that sweet, kind hearted, laughter-loving Gentleman, my young mistresses favourite.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Yes; and I knows he to be innocent— for I myself shewed him into the castle—and if so be, I had na been afraid of ghostesses, I would ha' gone in too.

sp.speaker: Annette.
sp.p:
Dear, dear, how my poor young lady will take on—she was so eager to see her sis
ter again, and so anxious to find her lover again, that she prevailed on Valoury, Carlos' servant, late as it was, to endeavour to hire a boat—and I shou'dn't be at all surprized if she was to cross the bay to the castle this very night—hist! isn't that music on the water.

div.stage: Some notes of music are heard at a distance.

sp.speaker: Cloddy.
sp.p: Yes—sure enough it is— hark! it comes nearer—its some boatmen singing as they row to shore—let us hide ourselves again.

div.stage:
A row-gally with lighted lantherns on board is seen at a distance, rowing towards the shore—music and voices are distinguish'd, Chorus at first faintly heard, gradually growing louder—a noise like the splashing of oars occa
sionally distinguished.

sp.speaker: Chorus of Boatmen.
sp.l: As we plow the placid main,
Now of Scylla's rock take care—
Hold—now take the staff in hand;
Spring on shore—we've reach'd the land.

body.stage: CONSTANTIA, veiled is handed out of the galley by VALOURY.

sp.speaker: VALOURY.
sp.l: 'Tis so dark, I wond'rous glad am,

sp.speaker: CONSTANTIA
sp.l: Thank ye, friends, for all your trouble,
Stay, and I'll reward ye doubles

sp.speaker: Chorus of Boatmen.
sp.l: Glad we wait for your commands.

sp.speaker: CONSTANTIA.
sp.l: Tell us where the Castle stands.

sp.speaker: Chorus of Boatmen.
sp.l: There it hath for ages stood.

sp.speaker: ANNETTE
sp.stage: —coming forward, as they are going off.
sp.l: Stop, dearest lady—the birds are all flown—
Your father—your sister, your lover are gone.

sp.speaker: CLODDY
sp.l: The old one, for certain, has carried them off.

sp.speaker: CONSTANTIA.
sp.l: Annette, is it you—do you treat us with scoff?

sp.speaker: VALOURY, CLODDY, and CHORUS.
sp.l: What old one, what old one, has carried them off?

sp.speaker: Duett—ANNETTE and CLODDY.
sp.l: If you stay, you'll be undone.

body.stage: Voices without, echoed by voices in several gallies coming to them.

sp.speaker: CLODDY.
sp.l: As we told you, we're undone.

sp.speaker: Chorus of Sailors—landing.
sp.l: Stop, and seize them every one.

sp.speaker:
Chorus—CLODDY, VALOURY, ANNETTE and CON
STANTIA.
Chorus of Soldiers—rushing from the wings.

body.stage: Chorus of Soldiers returning with CLODDY, VALOURY, Ladies, &c. Sailors assisting

sp.speaker: MONTAUBAN.
sp.l: Straight to prison you must go.

sp.speaker: Chorus of Soldiers, &c.
sp.l: When you suffer, you will know—

sp.speaker: VALOURY and CLODDY.
sp.l: Oh, ho, ho, ho! Oh, ho, ho!
That will be too late to know.

body.stage:
Duet—CONSTANTIA on one side of MONTAUBAN, AN
